Award.AbstractNarration:
Among of the most exciting events of recent years has been the mounting evidence that the very early universe underwent a period of accelerated expansion known as primordial inflation. During primordial inflation there is a vast enhancement of quantum effects, which are ordinarily very small. These quantum effects can become so strong that conventional techniques for computing them break down. The main goal of this project is to develop new techniques for reliably computing these quantum effects, so that people can know precisely what they are. Another goal is to search for observable consequences of these enhanced quantum effects that may be masquerading as modifications of the gravitational force.

Such a study is interesting because many aspects of the current universe can only be understood, without using quantum effects, by supposing that cosmological evolution is driven by enormous quantities (about 96% of the total) of exotic mass and energy that has not been detected in Earth-bound laboratories. It is possible that some of the inexplicable features of cosmology are the result of quantum effects that became strong during primordial inflation. The broader impacts of this project lie in the promotion of teaching, training and learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Quantum phenomena arise due to fluctuations in the positions and velocities of particles, and in the strengths of force fields. These fluctuations are quite small under the conditions that prevail today, but they can be much larger when the universe is expanding rapidly. This project concerns quantum phenomena in the very early universe, during a phase of exceptionally rapid expansion known as "primordial inflation." Even though primordial inflation occurred almost 14 billion years ago, fossilized remnants of the quantum fluctuations from this time have been detected, and the secondary effects they induce may play an important role in the current state of the universe. The problem is how to use the data to reconstruct the physical laws which pertained during primordial inflation, and also to predict what should be going on today. Given a fundamental theory, physicists by now agree on how to predict the primary effect of quantum fluctuations, but there is much debate about how to predict secondary effects. For example, one primary effect consists of small spatial variations --- which have been measured --- in the energy per unit volume of the universe, and a typical secondary effect would be the gravitational attraction between these small variations.  A major component of this research project has been to settle some of the disputes about how to predict these sorts of secondary effects.

A second component of this project has been to use the new formalism to make explicit predictions. These computations are so difficult that every one of them stands as a major achievement in its own right. Two kinds of particles turn out to be responsible for all important quantum effects during primordial inflation: particles like the Higgs boson whose discovery has just been reported at the Large Hadron Collider, and gravitational radiation. The first kind have zero spin, whereas the second kind have spin two. A major result from the project has been to establish the importance of nonzero spin in producing large secondary quantum effects.

It is too difficult to compute most quantum effects exactly, so approximation techniques must be employed. These techniques are generally valid as long as the effects are small, but they break down when the effects become large. One surprising result of making explicit computations of secondary quantum effects during primordial inflation is that they grow with time. This means they eventually become so large that standard approximation techniques break down. A third major component of this project has been to develop a formalism for making ``educated guesses'' about what might happen after secondary quantum effects from primordial inflation become large. A major consequence of these educated guesses is that secondary effects from primordial inflation eventually become strong enough to end the rapid expansion, and that they induce a subsequent phase in which the expansion rate oscillates.

The final component of this proposal concerns changing perceptions about the problem of incorporating quantum fluctuations in the gravitational field generally, not just during primordial inflation. To this end the PI wrote a pedagogical review article for the journal, Reports on Progress in Physics, and he has been giving colloquia on it around the world. Among the points he is trying to establish are: (1) The problem of quantum gravity is not and never has been with gravitational radiation but rather with how classical gravity responds to quantum fluctuations in ordinary matter; (2)  cosmology is changing the way we perceive quantum grvaity; and (3) the first recognizable quantum gravitational effects ever observed are the fossilized quantum fluctuations from the epoch of primordial inflation.
